body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

Issue #64 was marked as a duplicate of this issue.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

Issue #196 was marked as a duplicate of this issue.

**zvell wrote:**

Is there a workaround that can be used while this is open? Perhaps manually changing the migration script?
``--autogenerate`` currently created ``sa.Column('ts', sa.DateTime(), server_default='now()', nullable=True),`` which gets translated to ``ALTER TABLE revision ALTER COLUMN ts SET DEFAULT '2014-04-28 12:22:16.485989'::timestamp without time zone;``. Is there anything I can replace ``server_default='now()'`` with to force it to render to sql properly? I'm using PostgreSQL 9.1.13 and alembic==0.6.4.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

yes, manually changing the migration script is what you're supposed to do.  You might notice the script that's generated even has a comment encouraging this.   This is why autogenerate migrations are called ["candidate migrations"](http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/tutorial.html#auto-generating-migrations).

**zvell wrote:**

Oh, yes of course. I guess I was fishing for a solution for my specific problem.

I found a workaround by issuing
`` op.execute('ALTER TABLE table ALTER COLUMN ts SET DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP::timestamp without time zone')`` after the automatically generated commands.

**zvell wrote:**

The same behaviour applies for other server_defaults (e.g. boolean value=False).

If I manually change the migration script to

>  `` op.create_table('product',
>      sa.Column('deleted', sa.Boolean(), nullable=True, server_default=False),
>      ...
>  ``

which is kind of as per the [docs](http://alembic.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ops.html#alembic.operations.Operations.add_column), I get this exception on running `upgrade`

>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/alembic/compat.py", line 58, in load_module_py
>    mod = imp.load_source(module_id, path, fp)
>  File "/Users/u/app/migration/env.py", line 95, in <module>
>    run_migrations_online()
>  File "/Users/u/app/migration/env.py", line 88, in run_migrations_online
>    context.run_migrations()
>  File "<string>", line 7, in run_migrations
>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/alembic/environment.py", line 681, in run_migrations
>    self.get_context().run_migrations(**kw)
>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/alembic/migration.py", line 225, in run_migrations
>    change(**kw)
>  File "/Users/u/app/migration/versions/45c9f48e46dc_revision_products.py", line 21, in upgrade
>    sa.Column('deleted', sa.Boolean(), nullable=True, server_default=False),
>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql/schema.py", line 1055, in __init__
>    args.append(DefaultClause(self.server_default))
>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/sql/schema.py", line 2114, in __init__
>    TextClause), 'arg')
>  File "/Users/u/env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/util/langhelpers.py", line 1022, in assert_arg_type
>    (name, ' or '.join("'%s'" % a for a in argtype), type(arg)))
>sqlalchemy.exc.ArgumentError: Argument 'arg' is expected to be one of type '<type 'basestring'>' or '<class 'sqlalchemy.sql.elements.>ClauseElement'>' or '<class 'sqlalchemy.sql.elements.TextClause'>', got '<type 'bool'>'

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

"False" isn't a SQL expression, which server_default requires.   the alembic docs you refer to illustrate `text()`, which indicates a literal SQL string.  Here's the [main docs](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/core/defaults.html#server-side-defaults) for server_default - it only deals with strings and SQL expression elements.  you can send it something like `text("false")`, `sqlalchemy.sql.False_`, etc.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

the exception message is also pretty specific, it's telling you what types it expects.  Guess it's not clear enough what those types are....

**zvell wrote:**

You are right. The exception message was specific and clear, but I assumed I could have given `server_default` a Python type and it would just translate it into sql-specifics (potential feature?).

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

we also seek to include expressions like cast(), see #218

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **title** from "support rendering of func.XYZ() func.XYZ(simple co" to "support rendering of func.XYZ() func.XYZ(simple co"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

see https://github.com/zzzeek/alembic/pull/16 which has a lot of this

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

also see #222 which contains some infrastructure to support this

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- changelog for #197, fixes #197.

issue.title: declared_attr __table_args__ are not taken into account

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.title: support functional indexes with op.create_index()

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek))**

op.create_index() only accepts string column names.  Particularly with autogenerate and issue #197, we need to be able to put expressions in here without needing a Column object lying around.   So let's allow text():

    op.create_index("foo", "table", text("lower('x')"), text("lower('y')"))

issue.title: psycopg2 error in autogenerated migrations with func.current_timestamp()

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Kim SilkebÃ¦kken ([@Lokaltog](https://github.com/Lokaltog))**

When creating models for Postgres/psycopg2 that have a column with a `server_default=func.current_timestamp()`, this statement gets replaced with `server_default='CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'` in the actual migration file. This raises the exception `psycopg2.NotSupportedError: date/time value "current" is no longer supported` when attempting to migrate, and to resolve this issue I have to manually edit the migrations file and replace the server default back to `func.current_timestamp()`.

Example:

```
# Model:
from sqlalchemy.sql import func

class Test(Base):
	created = Column(DateTime, server_default=func.current_timestamp())

# Resulting migration:
def upgrade():
	# ...
	sa.Column('created', sa.DateTime(), server_default='CURRENT_TIMESTAMP')
	# ...

```

I'm not sure if this is intended behavior (or if it's fixable through some configuration option), but if this issue is possible to resolve by e.g. detecting the database backend or just re-using the actual model definition that would be awesome.

issue.title: Quoting bug in server_default values

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by nickretallack ([@nickretallack](https://github.com/nickretallack))**

It generates bad SQL when I set ```server_default="timezone('utc'::text, now())"```.

Original schema:

```
class Timestamps(db.Model):
    created_at = db.Column(db.DateTime, nullable=False, server_default=db.text("timezone('utc'::text, now())"))
```

Generated migration:

```
op.create_table('timestamps',
sa.Column('created_at', sa.DateTime(), server_default="timezone('utc'::text, now())", nullable=False)
)
```

Generated SQL:

```
CREATE TABLE timestamps (
	created_at TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE DEFAULT 'timezone('utc'::text, now())' NOT NULL,
)
```

Error:

```
sqlalchemy.exc.ProgrammingError: (ProgrammingError) syntax error at or near "utc"
LINE 3: ...at TIMESTAMP WITHOUT TIME ZONE DEFAULT 'timezone('utc'::text...
```

If there's one quoting error, there may be more.  Be careful about this, as bad quoting could really screw things up.

issue.title: server_default=text('...') lost in generated migration

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

repository.name: alembic
repository.description: A database migrations tool for SQLAlchemy.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by B. Candler ([@candlerb](https://github.com/candlerb))**

Given a new field added to a (mysql) database model, in a Flask app with Flask-SQLAlchemy:

~~~
    sometime = db.Column(db.DateTime, server_default=db.text('CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'))
~~~

this generates the following migration:

~~~
def upgrade():
    ### commands auto generated by Alembic - please adjust! ###
    op.add_column('msg_in', sa.Column('sometime', sa.DateTime(), server_default='CURRENT_TIMESTAMP', nullable=True))
    ### end Alembic commands ###
~~~

(note that `db.text()` has gone)

which fails because the text has become a quoted string literal:

~~~
sqlalchemy.exc.OperationalError: (OperationalError) (1067, "Invalid default value for 'sometime'") "ALTER TABLE msg_in ADD COLUMN sometime DATETIME DEFAULT 'CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'" ()
~~~

Workaround: manually modify the generated migration to wrap the field with sa.text()

~~~
    op.add_column('msg_in', sa.Column('sometime', sa.DateTime(), server_default=sa.text('CURRENT_TIMESTAMP'), nullable=True))
~~~

(which generates the correct SQL, although note you still need mysql 5.6+ for this to work)

Tested with:

alembic (0.6.7)
Flask-Migrate (1.2.0)
Flask-SQLAlchemy (1.0)
MySQL-python (1.2.5)
SQLAlchemy (0.9.8)
